intro: Psacalium putlanum, commonly known as the Mexican nightshade, is a flowering plant native to Central America and northern South America. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like tomatoes and peppers. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. Its fruits are berries that mature to a dark purple color and contain several seeds. Psacalium putlanum is often found in tropical and subtropical regions, growing in moist, shaded environments.
